messages.content:
You are a professional academic reference prediction expert. Your task is to predict the most likely references for a given academic paper based on its title, abstract, and retrieved relevant papers.

RETRIEVER INTERFACE:
- Input: paper title + abstract
- Output: {top_r} retrieved papers with title and abstract
- Format: List of dictionaries with 'title' and 'abstract' fields

REQUIREMENTS:
1. Analyze the paper's title and abstract to understand its research area and focus
2. Consider the retrieved papers as potential references (when available)
3. Generate a list of predicted reference titles that would be most relevant and likely to be cited
4. Provide reasoning for each prediction to prevent hallucination
5. Output format: JSON object with "titles" array and "reasoning" string
6. Generate exactly 48 most relevant reference titles (this should be at least 40 to cover all evaluation metrics)
7. Ensure titles are realistic and appropriate for the research area
8. Consider citation patterns in the field
9. CRITICAL: Each title must be unique - never repeat the same title multiple times

EXAMPLE:
Input:
Title: "Question Type Classification Methods Comparison"
Abstract: "The paper presents a comparative study of state-of-the-art approaches for question classification task: Logistic Regression, Convolutional Neural Networks (CNN), Long Short-Term Memory Network (LSTM) and Quasi-Recurrent Neural Networks (QRNN). All models use pre-trained GLoVe word embeddings and trained on human-labeled data. The best accuracy is achieved using CNN model with five convolutional layers and various kernel sizes stacked in parallel, followed by one fully connected layer. The model reached 90.7% accuracy on TREC 10 test set."

Retrieved papers ({top_r}):
1. Title: Convolutional Neural Networks for Sentence Classification
   Abstract: We report on a series of experiments with convolutional neural networks trained on top of pre-trained word vectors for sentence-level classification tasks.

2. Title: Glove: Global vectors for word representation
   Abstract: We present a new global log-bilinear regression model that combines the advantages of the two major model families in the literature.

Output:
{
  "titles": [
    "Convolutional Neural Networks for Sentence Classification",
    "Glove: Global vectors for word representation",
    "Quasi-Recurrent Neural Networks",
    "A Comparative Study of Neural Network Models for Sentence Classification",
    "Deep lstm based feature mapping for query classification"
  ],
  "reasoning": "Based on the paper's focus on question classification using neural networks, I predict these references because: 1) CNN paper is directly relevant to the convolutional approach used; 2) GloVe embeddings are mentioned as pre-trained features; 3) QRNN is one of the compared methods; 4) Comparative study papers are common in this field; 5) LSTM-based query classification is closely related to question classification. Additional references cover related neural network architectures, NLP applications, deep learning methodologies, optimization techniques, and advanced neural network methods that would be relevant for this research area."
}

Return JSON object only.

Paper Title: Optimal transportation for electrical impedance tomography

Paper Abstract: Abstract. This work establishes a framework for solving inverse boundary problems with the geodesic based quadratic Wasserstein distance (W2subscriptùëä2W_{2}). A general form of the Fr√©chet gradient is systematically derived by optimal transportation (OT) theory. In addition, a fast algorithm based on the new formulation of OT on ùïä1superscriptùïä1\mathbb{S}^{1} is developed to solve the corresponding optimal transport problem. The computational complexity of the algorithm is reduced to O‚Äã(N)ùëÇùëÅO(N) from O‚Äã(N3)ùëÇsuperscriptùëÅ3O(N^{3}) of the traditional method. Combining with the adjoint-state method, this framework provides a new computational approach for solving the challenging electrical impedance tomography (EIT) problem. Numerical examples are presented to illustrate the effectiveness of our method.

{retrieved_text}

Generate exactly 48 most likely reference titles for this paper. Focus on papers that are directly related to the research topic, provide foundational background, present similar methodologies, or address related problems.

CRITICAL: Each title must appear exactly once. Do not repeat any title.

IMPORTANT: You must respond with ONLY valid JSON in this exact format:
{
    "titles": [
        "Reference Title 1",
        "Reference Title 2",
        "Reference Title 3",
        "Reference Title 4",
        "Reference Title 48"
    ],
    "reasoning": "Explain why you chose these specific references based on the paper's title, abstract, and retrieved papers. This helps prevent hallucination and ensures relevance."
}

Do not include any text before or after the JSON. Do not include authors, venues, or years - only the paper titles. The reasoning field is required to explain your prediction logic.

{
    "titles": [
        "Tomographic reconstruction from a few views: a multi-marginal optimal transport approach",
        "Electrical Impedance Tomography: methods, history and applications",
        "A user‚Äôs guide to optimal transport",
        "Inverse scattering problems with multi-frequencies",
        "Numerical solution of inverse problems by weak adversarial networks",
        "A computational fluid mechanics solution to the Monge-Kantorovich mass transfer problem",
        "Numerical solution of the optimal transportation problem using the Monge‚ÄìAmp√®re equation",
        "Electrical impedance tomography",
        "Polar factorization and monotone rearrangement of vector valued functions",
        "Boundary regularity of maps with convex potentials‚ÄìII",
        "On an inverse boundary value problem",
        "The quadratic Wasserstein metric for earthquake location",
        "NOSER: An algorithm for solving the inverse conductivity problem",
        "Electrical impedance tomography using level set representation and total variational regularization",
        "Sinkhorn distances: Lightspeed computation of optimal transport",
        "Fast transport optimization for Monge costs on the circle",
        "Application of the Wasserstein metric to seismic signals",
        "The quadratic Wasserstein metric for inverse data matching",
        "Optimal transport based seismic inversion: Beyond cycle skipping",
        "Solving electrical impedance tomography with deep learning",
        "Optimal transport and curvature",
        "Optical design of single reflector systems and the Monge‚ÄìKantorovich mass transfer problem",
        "Wasserstein-based projections with applications to inverse problems",
        "Optimal mass transport for registration and warping",
        "Distinguishability of conductivities by electric current computed tomography",
        "A reconstruction algorithm for electrical impedance tomography based on sparsity regularization",
        "Mathematical methods of organizing and planning production",
        "A variational algorithm for electrical impedance tomography",
        "Numerical implementation of a variational method for electrical impedance tomography",
        "Automated Solution of Differential Equations by the Finite Element Method",
        "Polar factorization of maps on Riemannian manifolds",
        "A graph space optimal transport distance as a generalization of LpsubscriptùêøùëùL_{p} distances: application to a seismic imaging inverse problem",
        "An optimal transport approach for seismic tomography: application to 3D full waveform inversion",
        "M√©moire sur la th√©orie des d√©blais et des remblais",
        "Sobolev Gradients and Differential Equations",
        "Computational optimal transport: With applications to data science",
        "Comparison between W2subscriptùëä2W_{2} distance and HÀô‚àí1superscriptÀôùêª1\\dot{H}^{-1} norm, and localization of Wasserstein distance",
        "Transportation distances on the circle",
        "Convex Analysis",
        "Enhanced electrical impedance tomography via the Mumford‚ÄìShah functional",
        "Optimal Transport for Applied Mathematicians",
        "Convolutional Wasserstein distances: Efficient optimal transportation on geometric domains",
        "Electrical impedance tomography and Calder√≥n‚Äôs problem",
        "Topics in Optimal Transportation",
        "On the design of a reflector antenna II",
        "Impedance-computed tomography algorithm and system",
        "Application of optimal transport and the quadratic Wasserstein metric to full-waveform inversion",
        "The Wasserstein-Fisher-Rao metric for waveform based earthquake location"
    ],
    "reasoning": "Selected these 48 references because they represent foundational work and recent advances in Optimal transportation for electrical impedance tomography, providing essential background knowledge and methodological foundations relevant to this research."
}
